newsitem.title: USA: U.S. Mid-West power prices ease in quiet trade.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Mid-West power prices ease in quiet trade.

text.p: Wholesale spot electricity prices for the U.S. Mid-West were mostly lower Tuesday in quiet trade ahead of some warmer weather and weakening holiday demand, industry sources said.
Tough winter cold was expected to ease in northern states, reaching highs above the freezing level Wednesday. Winter cold was again forecast to move into the area however from December 1 to 5.
Spot trade was said to be fairly thin through the Mid-West, with many traders planning to take Wednesday off ahead of the U.S. Thanksgiving Day holiday.

In the Mid-Continent Area Power Pool (MAPP), peak non-firm next day power deals for Wednesday delivery were pegged lower with talk at $25.00-27.00 from $27.50-29.50 per megawatt hour (MWh) on Monday, the brokers and marketers said.
Many traders were sewing up deals through to the end of the holiday weekend at $15.00-18.00 per MWh.
Off-peak non-firm MAPP power deals were notionally pegged steady in the $12.00-14.00 range, the sources said.
In the Mid-American Interpool Network (MAIN) peak, non-firm power for Wednesday delivery was pegged higher at $27.00-31.00 from $25.00-27.00 on Monday, again with few 16-hour deals being done.
MAIN power through to the end of the weekend was also trading at $15.00-16.00 per MWh.
MAIN off peak power was said to be steady at $12.00-14.00.

Peak, non-firm electricity prices in the East Central Area Reliability Coordination Agreement (ECAR) for Wednesday delivery were assessed at $25.00-27.00 from $27.00-28.00 on Monday, the sources said.
Off-peak next-day ECAR power was notionally assessed steady at $13.00-15.00.
December peak ECAR was talked steady at $22.00-23.00, with January/February ECAR also assessed steady at $23.00-24.00 per MWh.
Peak non-firm power prices in the Southwest Power Pool (SPP) for Wednesday delivery were talked higher at $27.00-29.00, the sources said.
Off-peak prices throughout SPP were notionally said to be steady in the $13.00-15.00 area.
December SPP was assessed lower at $24.00-26.50 from $25.00-27.00 on Monday, while January/February was pegged at $27.00-27.50 per MWh.
